Comment: I've annotated this game simply because it was my first in Gameknot (i.e. there's nothing to recommend the game), and done so without the aid of a computer, so there are likely flaws in the analysis.

Morphy's defence, the main line of the Ruy Lopez. I believe the logic is that it forces White into an early decision without losing a tempo, and is also the first move of a possible queenside pawn advance.

Still in the main line of the Ruy Lopez. Black can and does capture on e4 (the Open/Tarrasch Defense), but White gets very good chances by attacking on the e-file.

Better than the immediate Re1, d4 tries to open the e-file and develops the Bc1.
Better than the immediate Re1, d4 tries to open the e-file and develops the Bc1.

?! Here we leave the "World" database, but not the Gameknot database. 7... f5 is tempting because 7... d5 pins the Nc6, but after 8. Nxd4, f5 is attacked, and a route to the Black king has been opened.

The most popular line in the Gameknot database is 8... Qh4 9. g3 Qf6 10. Nxc6 bxc6 11. f3 Bc5+ 12. Kg2 O-O 13. fxe4 fxe4 where White is up a piece for two pawns but Black has a dangerous looking attack. The game move is probably prioritising material; I have no idea which is better.

The most popular line in the Gameknot database is 8... Qh4 9. g3 Qf6 10. Nxc6 bxc6 11. f3 Bc5+ 12. Kg2 O-O 13. fxe4 fxe4 where White is up a piece for two pawns but Black has a dangerous looking attack. The game move is probably prioritising material; I have no idea which is better.
Be7 is thematic in the Ruy Lopez, protecting the king against pins while allowing castling. Here, the g7 pawn is too important to lose. But does Black have anything better?
Be7 is thematic in the Ruy Lopez, protecting the king against pins while allowing castling. Here, the g7 pawn is too important to lose. But does Black have anything better?
A natural forcing move, although the knight is re-pinned. 10. Rf8 is also worth considering.
A natural forcing move, although the knight is re-pinned. 10. Rf8 is also worth considering.

? Black now seems to be lost, even at my lower standard. The threat on f2 is an illusion after 12. Qh5+ and 13. Qxf5, whereas Black has opened the h4-d8 diagonal for White's bishop without doing any thing to activate pieces such as Rh8 and Bc7. Better options include 11... c6 and 11... Rf8.

Not 19. fxe4? b5 20. Bb3 c4, trapping the bishop. Credit to Black for resigning now when some would have played on hoping (not unrealistically) for a blunder from White.
